[Born Lucky](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BornLucky): His lucky coin gives you "The Luck of the Emperor" ability, which increases your Luck stat.

[Founder of the Kingdom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FounderOfTheKingdom):  (SPOILER)  If he is Talos, then as Tiber Septim he was the one who founded the Third Empire. He seems to take its decline in stride, though. 
QUOTE **Wulf**:The Emperor is getting old. Don't know how much longer he'll hang on. So is the whole Empire, for that matter. Getting old, that is. The Emperor and the legions have held the Empire together for hundreds of years. It's been a good thing, by and large. But maybe it's time for a change. Time for something young and new. What? No idea. Because I'm old. Old dog doesn't get new ideas. But maybe young folks like you should try some new ideas. I don't know. Could be messy. But change is never pretty.
[God in Human Form](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodInHumanForm):  (SPOILER)  He's an avatar of Talos.

[God Was My Co-Pilot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodWasMyCoPilot): That old man who asks you to carry his coin into Red Mountain is none other than  (SPOILER) Tiber Septim/Talos himself .
QUOTE **Lalatia Varian**: I hesitate to suggest it. But I think you have been visited by an aspect of  (SPOILER)  Tiber Septim.  Surely this is a sign of a great doom laid upon you by the gods.

[Permanently Missable Content](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PermanentlyMissableContent): He will only appear in Ghostgate after receiving Wraithguard from Vivec, and will disappear once you leave Ghostgate or finish the quest without visiting it. As such, it's fairly easy to miss him.
[Batman Gambit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BatmanGambit): How he tricks a spy into poisoning himself in *[A Game at Dinner](http://www.uesp.net/wiki/Lore:A_Game_at_Dinner)*.

[Black-and-Gray Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackAndGrayMorality): He's the (dark) Gray to  (SPOILER)  Almalexia's  Black. Sure, he has his moments of very dark morality, but many of them have [Pragmatic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy) (if selfish) reasons behind them and he's certainly better than  (SPOILER) a [Physical God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PhysicalGod) of [decreasing sanity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SanitySlippage) who plans to kill her fellow former deities and the [Player Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayerCharacter) to be martyrs in her new monotheistic religion revolving around her .

[Bluffing the Murderer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BluffingTheMurderer): As described in the in-game book *A Game at Dinner*, he implies to his assembled dinner guests that he put poison on the cutlery of someone spying against him, then invites any spies present to take a dose of the antidote, kept in a tureen at the centre of the table. One of the spies loses his nerve and drinks, only for Helseth to reveal that no-one's cutlery was poisoned. The poison was, in fact, the 'antidote' the spy was just bluffed into drinking.
[Carrying the Antidote](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CarryingTheAntidote): Subverted. See [Bluffing the Murderer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BluffingTheMurderer) above.

[The Chessmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChessmaster): Along with [Manipulative Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManipulativeBastard). Fail to capture the throne of Wayrest during the events of *[Daggerfall?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/TheElderScrollsIIDaggerfall)* He returns to his mother's homeland and captures the throne there. The former King Llethan is old and weak?  (SPOILER)  Helseth poisons him and usurps his throne, killing Llethan's chosen heir in the process . Some "Nerevarine" character is making news in Vvardenfell? He sends the Dark Brotherhood to kill the Nerevarine.  (SPOILER)  When that fails, Helseth gets the Nerevarine to work for *him* . The in-game book *A Game at Dinner* also provides a great example, in which Helseth roots out a spy.

[Klingon Promotion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KlingonPromotion):  (SPOILER) He gives one to the *[Player Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayerCharacter)*, hiring them as his new catspaw after they obliterate the Dark Brotherhood assassins he'd sent after them.

[Master Poisoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterPoisoner): He is reputed to be one of the best and most subtle poisoners in the world. While the official claim is that his predecessor died of old age, everyone close to the former king believes that he was poisoned.

[Murder, Inc.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MurderInc): He's very fond of sending the Dark Brotherhood to eliminate potential threats to him.
    - [Assassin Outclassin'](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssassinOutclassin): (SPOILER) His assassins are, of course, no match for the Nerevarine. These failed assassination attempts start off the plot for *Tribunal* .

[Praetorian Guard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PraetorianGuard): The Royal Guards of Mournhold.
    - [Cadre of Foreign Bodyguards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CadreOfForeignBodyguards): His strongest bodyguard, Karrod, is a Redguard. The Captain of the Royal Guards, Tienius Delitian, is an Imperial. Alusannah, another Redguard, is the personal bodyguard of Helseth's mother Barenziah.

[Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy):  (SPOILER)  Sends the Dark Brotherhood after the player not out of any personal malice, but because he's worried this sudden wildcard upending the status quo in Vvardenfell could be a threat to his rule. Once his assassins are defeated and he gets a feel for your intentions, he seamlessly shifts into *using* the Nerevarine to instead sure up his rule and blunt the influence of the Temple.

[Puppet King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuppetKing): What his position has been prior to his ascension to the throne. The Tribunal Temple, Great Houses, and higher-ups in the Empire held any and all real power. Helseth is working to change that...

[The Quisling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheQuisling): He (along with House Hlaalu in general) is seen as this by the more conservative Dunmeri Great Houses (particularly the [Redorans](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudWarriorRace) and [Indoril](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReligiousBruiser)) for his significant ties to the Empire.

[Sketchy Successor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SketchySuccessor): To begin with, the Dunmer people see the role as "King of Morrowind" as an Imperial convention they have no need for, as they see their true rulers as the Tribunal Temple and the Great Houses. Helseth himself is a polarizing figure. The more conservative Dunmer in House Redoran and House Indoril feel he is a [Quisling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheQuisling) or [puppet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuppetKing) for the Empire, and he has a pattern of nepotism favoring his own House Hlaalu. He is also rumored to be a [Master Poisoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterPoisoner) who isn't above using the Dark Brotherhood to eliminate perceived threats. His predecessor as King and that King's chosen heir both died under mysterious circumstances, with Helseth believed to have been involved.  (SPOILER)  He also ends up being the last King of Morrowind, though not due to any political blunders. (Helseth appears to have been rather competent, and well on his way to transforming the role of King of Morrowind into a position with actual power at his last mention), but because of the Red Year; the post-Red Year Morrowind appears to be an aristocratic republic ruled by a council of the Great Houses (much like the situation prior to the Imperial takeover, although with the theocratic elements toned down) .

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): He apparently remains King until at least the [Oblivion Crisis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/TheElderScrollsIVOblivion). After that, he vanishes from any official lore.
[Alphabetical Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlphabeticalThemeNaming): If you think of it, you'll notice his "daughters" are named after Greek letters: Alfe, Beyte, Delte, and Uupse.

[Badass Bystander](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBystander): The strongest mortal on Vvardenfell, and also has zero interest in the machinations of Dagoth Ur or the Tribunal. His only involvement in the main plot is largely accidential, and once he's "cured" the Neravarine of Corpus he goes right back to his research.
[Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton): Even in self-defense, killing the patients within the Corprusarium will earn you his ire.

[The Collector of the Strange](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCollectorOfTheStrange): He has amassed quite the collection of legendary artifacts, and has even set up a [Lock and Key Puzzle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LockAndKeyPuzzle) for those willing to risk their lives (to either his violent Corprus victims or catching the disease themselves) to try to steal them. In particular, he has a number of Dwemer artifacts and items associated with the [Imperial Battlespire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/AnElderScrollsLegendBattlespire) event.

[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): Combine him being about 4000 years old with the other tropes listed here, and this is what you get. According to one of his daughter/wives, he's one of the oldest non-divine beings in Tamriel and still a powerful wizard. (According to the construction set files, he's level 65 - the highest of any NPC in the game.) He's also decked out in the only complete suit of Daedric armor in the vanilla game.

[Dark Is Not Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsNotEvil): Has the dark skin and red eyes typical of the Dunmer, wears a full suit of [Red and Black Daedric armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedAndBlackAndEvilAllOver), and is a former-ish member of [Great](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSorcerer) [House](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMagocracy) [Telvanni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightMakesRight) (he has dropped out of House affairs, but this isn't really all that strange for a Telvanni master wizard), but is nothing but cordial to the Nerevarine and greatly aids the Neravarine in the main quest.

[Dimensional Traveler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DimensionalTraveler): According to the in game book [The Doors of Oblivion](http://www.uesp.net/wiki/Lore:The_Doors_of_Oblivion), Fyr is one of the few "mortals" who can freely travel between the realms of the [Daedra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PhysicalGod).

[Dirty Old Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyOldMan): Downplayed toward his [Opposite-Sex Clone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OppositeSexClone) "daughters/wives." When discussing them, his love for them seems more fatherly than sexual, but it's hard to escape the implications [of this arrangement](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewYourself). Perhaps surprisingly, it isn't seen to be all that [Squicky](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Squick), at least within his tower.

[Find the Cure!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FindTheCure): He's searching for a cure for Corprus and possibly may have found one. [Sort of](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope).  (SPOILER) If he's to be believed, the Nerevarine *still* has Corprus and the potion he gave them just took away all the [negative effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodyHorror), while keeping the [positive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAgeless) [effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdealIllnessImmunity) in-tact. It's not technically a "cure" or even reliable as a vaccine, since aside from the Nerevarine, everyone else who had taken the potion died shortly afterwards.

[Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony): The only owner of a full set of Daedric armor in the vanilla game is a Telvanni wizard. (There are no *technical* gameplay-related downsides to wear Heavy Armor as a mage, but even great NPC mages will follow the rule of [squishy wizards do not wear armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmorAndMagicDontMix) for the sake of accurate world building.)

[Mage Tower](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MageTower): As with the other high-ranking Telvanni, he lives in a magically grown mushroom tower named after himself: Tel Fyr. The Corprusarium is in the basement, referred to as the "Bowels".

[Nightmare Fetishist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NightmareFetishist): Unlike most of Morrowind, he finds the Corprus disease highly fascinating to study despite it being highly contagious and usually lethal.

[Odd Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OddFriendship): With his former Argonian slave Vistha-Kai, who refused to leave when Fyr released his other slaves and now serves as the warden of the Corprusarium. According to Fyr, Vistha-Kai isn't much for conversation, but he does his job well and makes a good sparring partner for Fyr and his "daughters". Also with Yagrum Bagarn,  (SPOILER)  the last living Dwemer  and one of his earliest patients. Bagarn now spends his time tinkering with and fixing up any Dwemer artifacts that Fyr acquires.

[The Older Immortal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheOlderImmortal): He is this to the Telvanni councilors and Baladas Demnevanni, who, aside from Aryon, are all [Really 700 Years Old](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Really700YearsOld) themselves.
[Opposite-Sex Clone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OppositeSexClone): Has created four of these, who are variously referred to as his "daughters" or "wives".
[Really 700 Years Old](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReallySevenHundredYearsOld): Is said to be about 4,000 years old, one of the oldest non-divine beings on Tamriel.
[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass): Former member of the Psijic Order and a former councilor of House Telvanni. He left both to run his Corprusarium.
[Truly Single Parent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrulySingleParent): His "daughters" are really his own [Opposite Sex Clones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OppositeSexClone).

[Wizards Live Longer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WizardsLiveLonger): A wizard who's one of the oldest non-divine beings in Tamriel in this case. Exactly how he has lived this long isn't made explicitly clear, but it's implied to involve magic.
[And Your Reward Is Clothes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndYourRewardIsClothes): He gifts the the Nerevarine a set of enchanted clothes  (SPOILER) when he is recalled to the Imperial City .
[Bare-Fisted Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BareFistedMonk): He fights unarmed and unarmored, and can train you to do so. He's also a literal monk by class.

[Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton): Killing a fellow Blade or any of the characters he sends you to gather information from will cause him to fly into an extreme rage, breaking the main quest.
[Bullying a Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BullyingADragon): If you ask around the South Wall Cornerclub, you'll learn that people who make the mistake of underestimating Caius tend to disappear.

[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): Between having a rugged physique, being skilled in martial arts and a high ranking officer of the Empire secret service you can't deny Caius is a cool dude.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): And how.
QUOTE  "So. You say Hasphat Antabolis gave you notes to give to me? But you don't actuallly HAVE the notes? Perhaps... I hesitate to suggest it... you might go get the notes and bring them to me?"

[Get Out!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GetOut): Part of his reaction should the player break any of the rules of the Blades. He'll be [a lot louder about it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuddenlyShouting) if the player, [having no real reason to do so](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellPlayer), murders another Blade, one of his informants, or vital members of the Urshilaku camp.

[Good Old Fisticuffs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodOldFisticuffs): He's perpetually shirtless and shoeless, likely playing up his cover identity as a poor skooma addict, and is a trainer for the Hand-to-Hand and Unarmored skills.
[Grumpy Old Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrumpyOldMan): If you ask one of the other Blades about him, they call him "sour" and "a worrier."

tropeName: Jerk with a Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Jerk with a Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold): Despite the above, he very clearly cares about the player.

[Money for Nothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoneyForNothing): If the player reports to him prior to reaching level 4, he will gift the player 200 free gold with the instruction to use it to buy better gear or some training.

[Mr. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrExposition): He has an extremely high number of dialogue options which will fill in background details about the game's guilds and factions, as well as backstory details about Morrowind itself.

[Off the Grid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OffTheGrid): He uses this as part of his cover identity. He lives in a small one-room hovel at the edge of [Balmora](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HubCity), is [Obfuscating Stupidity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObfuscatingStupidity) and [Playing Drunk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingDrunk) as a [Skooma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticDrug) addict, and is [perpetually shirtless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingShirtlessScene) and wearing only common pants. Until you present him with the coded orders you received, he'll dismiss you and describe himself as "an old Skooma addict".

[Old Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OldMaster): He's definitely along in his years, but his stats and skills are better than most. He even fits the martial arts cliche of the trope, being one of the highest level trainers of the Hand to Hand skill.

[Playing Drunk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingDrunk): Along with elements of [Obfuscating Insanity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObfuscatingInsanity) and [Obfuscating Stupidity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObfuscatingStupidity). He pretends to be just another crazy skooma addict as part of his cover identity. Given that he is: a) the Imperial Spymaster, b) said to hold his "liquor" fairly well, and c) implied to have killed people who have underestimated him, it can be assumed it is all an act.

[Plot Detour](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlotDetour): At several points during the main quest, he will instruct the player to go off and do side quests in order to keep up his/her public identity as a freelance adventurer, and also to gain money and experience.

[Put on a Bus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PutOnABus): (SPOILER) He is recalled to the Imperial City about halfway through the main quest, never to be seen again. [Lore texts](http://www.imperial-library.info/content/ken-rolstons-texts) written by designer/developer Ken Rolston seem to indicate that Caius is alive and well following the Oblivion crisis.
[Quest Giver](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/QuestGiver): He is the primary one for the first act of the main quest.

[The Spymaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSpymaster): His mechanical rank in the Blades faction is *Grand* Spymaster <sup>note </sup>  a document that can be found indicates that lore-wise his title in the Blades proper is Knight-Errant , and one of the first documents he hands you refers to him as Director of Imperial Intelligence in Vvardenfell District. He is in charge of the Blades' operations in Vvardenfell, where their role is more about intel-gathering than Emperor-protecting.

[Unstoppable Rage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnstoppableRage): He will *[epically](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuddenlyShouting)* [lose his cool](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GetOut) if you screw up a quest for the Blades by killing someone you need to talk to, or kill a fellow Blade.
[Walking Shirtless Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingShirtlessScene): It's one his defining traits. It's likely done to play up his cover identity as a poor skooma addict.

[What the Hell, Player?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellPlayer): If the player does something deliberate to foul up one of his quests, such as killing one of his informants or a fellow Blade, Caius reacts... poorly. He'll give one of these speeches with [Sudden SHOUTING](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuddenlyShouting) and a permanent [Get Out!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GetOut), breaking the standard way of beating the main quest. If it's not murder that breaks the rules, he'll be a lot more cold about it.

[You Are in Command Now](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreInCommandNow): Leaves this instruction for  (SPOILER) the Nerevarine upon being recalled to the Imperial City . Of course, since the other Blades agents mostly do their own things and any orders from Cyrodiil to the contrary are liable to come with an actual superior, Caius basically tells you to ignore the big picture and just keep doing what you're already doing.
[The Ageless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAgeless): As a result of the Corprus Disease.

[But What About the Astronauts?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButWhatAboutTheAstronauts): This is how he survived the calamity which wiped out his people. He was in an undescribed "outer realm" at the time of the event and returned to Nirn to find them gone.
[Dimensional Traveler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DimensionalTraveler): In his past. He was in an undescribed "outer realm" when the calamity occurred that caused his people to vanish.

[Last of His Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHisKind):  (SPOILER) He's the last living Dwemer . He was in an undescribed "outer realm" when the calamity that wiped out his people occurred, and he returned to find them gone. He caught the Corprus Disease soon after and ended up in the Corprusarium.

[Legendary Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegendaryWeapon): The hammer Volendrung is in his possession. Additionally, he is the author of the book *[Famed Artifacts of Tamriel](http://en.uesp.net/wiki/Lore:Famed_Artifacts_of_Tamriel)* which details many other legendary items in Tamriellic lore.

[Nerdy Nasalness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NerdyNasalness): Unused voice files for Yagrum can be found in the [Construction Set](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LevelEditor). He speaks with a nasal, *nerdy* voice of all things.
[Really 700 Years Old](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReallySevenHundredYearsOld): Over 4000 thanks to the agelessness granted by the Corprus Disease.

[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass): He was a Master Crafter in service to Lord Kagrenac who spent time traveling to "outer realms." When he returned to find his people gone, he traveled all across Tamriel  (SPOILER) searching for any other Dwemer . He caught the Corprus Disease and was forcibly retired. He is still in possession of a full set of Dwemer armor, a stash of Dwemer coins, and the legendary hammer Volendrung.

[Super Wheelchair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperWheelchair): The Corprus disease has left him bloated and unable to use his legs, so he gets around on a throne with [spider legs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpiderMech) that's [steam powered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Steampunk).
[Take a Third Option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeAThirdOption):  (SPOILER)  His aid is absolutely crucial in the "Backpath" method to completing the game's main quest.

tropeName: These Are Things Man Was Not Meant to Know
tropeNotes: [These Are Things Man Was Not Meant to Know](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheseAreThingsManWasNotMeantToKnow): If you bring him *The Egg of Time* and *Divine Metaphysics* during the "[Mystery of the Dwarves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SnipeHunt)" quest for the Archmage Trebonius, he'll give you a report detailing [what Kagrenac was trying to achieve](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodhoodSeeker) and [why it failed so spectacularly](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoneHorriblyWrong), but redacts a lot of the details of Kagrenac's experiments so no one will try to replicate them.

[Ultimate Blacksmith](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UltimateBlacksmith): He is a  (SPOILER) Dwemer  Master Crafter and was in service to Lord Kagrenac prior, who was also one of these. He is the only person capable  (SPOILER) of "jury-rigging" the Wraithguard in the "Backpath" method to beating the main quest .

[Vocal Dissonance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VocalDissonance): You'd expect  (SPOILER)  a Dwemer  to have a deep commanding voice but no; instead, he sounds like your average stereotypical nerd with a bad case of the sniffles. [Justified](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustifiedTrope) as he actually is sick, and it may as well be another example of [how badly Corprus can affect its victims](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodyHorror).
[Author Avatar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AuthorAvatar): He voices the opinions of the game's creators toward a variety of topics, which is thinly veiled in his dialogue.

[Blatant Lies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlatantLies): All but two of his dialogue choices (Boethiah's Shrine and the Mudcrab Merchant) are completely false. Even with Boethiah's shrine, the directions he gives are [quite bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheComputerIsALyingBastard).

[Cloud Cuckoolander](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CloudCuckoolander): His nature justifiably makes him come off as *very* detached from the setting. Even beyond that, he is found fishing alone on a remote island wearing extravagant clothing and a stylish-but-impractical hat.

[The Cuckoolander Was Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCuckoolanderWasRight): Though the vast majority of his topics offer false information, he is correct about the sunken Shrine of Boethiah and the existence of the Mudcrab Merchant.
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Many of his comments are ripe with sarcasm.

[Easter Egg](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EasterEgg): He is a [Fourth-Wall Observer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourthWallObserver) [Author Avatar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AuthorAvatar) found alone a remote island.

[The Hilarity of Hats](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHilarityOfHats): The "silly hat" version. He wears a Colovian Fur Helm, essentially a yellow Santa Claus hat that stands straight up. Like the other characters in the game who wear one, it's a clear sign that he's not to be taken too seriously.

[Straw Fan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrawFan): Crossing over with [Take That, Audience!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeThatAudience), many of his comments are responses to features that the *ES* fandom wanted in *Morrowind*, but did not get (such as multi-player, moving corpses, nudity) or are responses to complaints of features from *Daggerfall* which were removed (such as horses and climbing).
[Arch-Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchEnemy): To the Thieves guild.

[Benevolent Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BenevolentBoss): Surprisingly enough. In a letter to his two most loyal enforcers, he warns them he plans to orchestrate his brother's demise and seize House Hlaalu for himself, and that if they don't want that kind of heat they can step out now and he won't hold it against them.
[Cain and Abel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel): You can actually find a note of his where he confirms that he is fully willing to have his brother killed.

[Dysfunctional Family](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DysfunctionalFamily): He leads a nationalistic crime syndicate, his brother is the Duke of Vvardenfell under the Empire, not to mention the head of a legitimate political faction with a firm pro-Imperial stance, and his niece runs with an underground abolitionist group. Needless to say they don't get along very well.
[Evil Uncle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilUncle): His brother's daughter Ilmeni is one of the most prominent abolitionists in the game, whereas he himself is one of the most prominent slavers.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): Unlike the thieves guild, the Cammona Tong doesn't accept foreigners into their ranks. As a result it is one of the very few factions in the game you cannot join.

Foil: To his own brother Vedam. Both are extremely powerful political forces trying to do what they think is best for the future of Morrowind and the Dunmer people. However whereas Vedam works openly as Duke of Vvardenfell, actively collaborates with the Imperials, and will go out of his way to request his brother not be killed if at all possible, Orvas works behind the scenes as a criminal kingpin, vehemently opposes the Imperial occupation, and is willing to get his hands dirty even if it means considering a hit on his brother.

[Hate Sink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HateSink): About as close as you can get in this game. He is the leader of a brutal and xenophobic criminal organisation, the greatest source of corruption in House Hlaalu, and, as if to drive the point home, the only faction leader in the game actually allied with [Dagoth Ur](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad). You don't actually have to kill him (or even deal with him at all, if you can amass enough reputation to skip the fourth and fifth trial), but aside from maybe [his brother](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThickerThanWater), few tears will be shed if you do.

[Occupiers Out of Our Country](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OccupiersOutOfOurCountry): Orvas' raison d'etre: he is willing to do anything to drive the Imperial occupiers as well as all outlanders from Morrowind, even if it means siding with Dagoth Ur.
[Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake)
[The Syndicate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSyndicate): He leads one.

[Threat Backfire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThreatBackfire): Any attempt to use the intimidation option, no matter how high your speechcraft skill, will immediately end the conversation and turn him hostile.
[Cain and Abel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel): The Cain to his brother's (Radd Hard-Heart) Abel. Radd is an honorable officer in the Imperial Legion.

[Challenging the Chief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChallengingTheChief):  (SPOILER) He will need to be killed [one way](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KlingonPromotion) or [another](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness) for you to take over as Master of the Fighter's Guild .
[Klingon Promotion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KlingonPromotion):  (SPOILER) Becoming Master of the Fighters Guild requires killing him .
[Leave No Survivors](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeaveNoSurvivors):  (SPOILER) His final quest involves killing the Master Thief of the Thieves Guild and his three Guild Hall Steward lieutenants .

[The Mole](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMole): He is deep in the pocket  (SPOILER) of the [Camonna Tong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSyndicate) who are using him (and the Fighters Guild) to wage war on their rivals, the Thieves Guild .

[You Have Outlived Your Usefulness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness):  (SPOILER) He will pull this on you if you complete his quest to wipe out the leadership of the Thieves Guild .
[Bounty Hunter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BountyHunter): The majority of his lower-level quests involve collecting bounties on murderers and bandits.
[The Creon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCreon): He is perfectly happy to  (SPOILER) let the Nerevarine take over as Guild Master once Sjoring has been dealt with  and will aid in any way he can.

[Heroes Prefer Swords](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroesPreferSwords): Is actively fighting the corruption within the Fighters Guild and wields a sword. His corrupt counterparts instead wield hammers, axes, or maces.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): He's one of the few honorable Fighters Guild Stewards remaining. If any of his more-corrupt counterparts give morally questionable orders, you can report to him for more reasonable alternatives.

[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass): He administrates the guild chapter in the somewhat remote city of Ald Ruhn, but at some point before the evens of the game he presided over the entire Fighters Guild of Vvardenfell. He stepped down voluntarily, referring to his relocation as a retirement, but he still has a very sharp sense of what's going on within the guild.
[Take a Third Option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeAThirdOption): He will offer alternative, less morally questionable means of completing quests for some of his corrupt Guild counterparts.
[Bounty Hunter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BountyHunter): Several of her quests involve hunting down known criminals.

[Bribe Backfire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BribeBackfire): As part of the Thieves Guild questline, she can be bribed  (SPOILER) into dropping her support for Sjoring with the Bitter Cup . However, if one also wants to complete the Fighters Guild quest line,  (SPOILER) she will still attack once the player receives the quest to eliminate Sjoring's minions even though she had been bribed previously .
[Deal with the Devil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DealWithTheDevil): She is a noted worshiper of Clavicus Vile, the Daedric Prince of Bargains and Wishes.

[Heel–Face Revolving Door](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceRevolvingDoor): She is initially sided with  (SPOILER) Sjoring , but she can be bribed via the Thieves Guild quest line to switch sides. However,  (SPOILER) if you then continue the Fighters Guild quest line, she will still attack you when you reach the quest to eliminate Sjoring's minions .

[Multi-Melee Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiMeleeMaster): Her Class is "Master-at-Arms" and she offers high-level training to Guild members of the Protector rank and higher. She can train in Axe (up to 72), Blunt Weapon (up to 72), and Long Blade (up to 67).
[Quest Giver](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/QuestGiver): She is the primary Fighters Guild quest giver for entry-level quests.
[Big Damn Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigDamnHeroes): Several of his quests require rescuing people who are trapped in hostile places in such a manner.
[Blackmail](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Blackmail): He can be blackmailed for his support as part of the Thieves Guild quest line.
[Bounty Hunter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BountyHunter): Offers a couple of these quests.

[Collection Sidequest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CollectionSidequest): His final (optional) quest is to retrieve the Seven Eggs of Gold from the Pudai Egg mine. Luckily, they're all in the same area, but they combine to weigh 210 lbs, which can make carrying them rather challenging.
[Hypercompetent Sidekick](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HypercompetentSidekick): One of his quests has you be this for an Imperial Legionnaire who is seeking revenge on a certain Daedroth.

[Interspecies Romance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InterspeciesRomance): He has taken a Dunmer woman as a lover.  (SPOILER) In order to gain his support as part of the Thieves Guild quest line, you'll need to blackmail him with this information. The "interspecies" part itself isn't the reason for the blackmail, rather, it's because this information puts his lover in danger should Sjoring and/or the Camonna Tong find out about her .
[Number Two](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NumberTwo): Formerly served as Percius' second-in-command before Sjoring took over.

[Genius Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusBruiser): He's a fighter first and foremost, he is in the Fighter's Guild. However, he's also an impressive archaeologist and theorist on the Dwemer. He's also an author, and has written several well known books that still exist centuries later in Skyrim.
[Gentleman and a Scholar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GentlemanAndAScholar): Incredibly polite, incredibly learned, and is a well-written author.

[Going Native](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoingNative): Downplayed. He's still an Imperial and writes about the establishment of the Nine. However, he is very comfortable with the notoriously icy natives of Morrowind, having worked alongside many mercenaries.

[Mr. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrExposition): As Caius's contact in the region, he is the guy who gives the Nerevarine his first taste of Vvardenfell's lore. Namely, he discusses the Sixth House, the Great Houses, and the Nerevarine prophecy.
[The Archmage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheArchmage): His title as leader of the Vvardenfell branch of the Mages Guild.
[Beware the Silly Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareTheSillyOnes): He may be an incompetent fool, but he’s still a powerful Battlemage.

[Disproportionate Retribution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisproportionateRetribution): While drunk, a member of Vivec's Office of the Watch insulted Trebonius. Trebonius responded by giving the guy a magical rash that will not go away.
[Energy Absorption](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnergyAbsorption): Wears the Necromancer’s Amulet, which gives him the ability to absorb incoming magic spells.
[General Ripper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeneralRipper): Decides that the best way of dealing with the Telvanni, native rivals to the Mages Guild, is to kill all of their councilors.
[Graceful Loser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GracefulLoser): If you end up becoming Guildmaster peacefully, he accepts the council’s decision with surprising dignity.

[The Horseshoe Effect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHorseshoeEffect): Despite his hostility toward the Telvanni, his eccentric demands and power without common sense actually make him very ideologically similar to a typical Telvanni mage lord. Even his solution toward handling the Telvanni is exactly what a typical Telvanni would do to deal with his rivals.

[Impossible Task](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpossibleTask): Crossing over with [Snipe Hunt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SnipeHunt), he has a habit of giving guild members duties they couldn’t possibly perform. Notably, he asks the player to find out about the [disappearance of the](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RiddleForTheAges) [Dwemer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurDwarvesAreDifferent) and is shocked when the player actually manages to find an answer. Other tasks he has assigned to guild members include taking inventory of all the silverware in Vvardenfell and digging a tunnel to the mainland.
[Kicked Upstairs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickedUpstairs): He was promoted to Arch-Mage of Vvardenfell in order to get him out of Cyrodiil, where his superiors were weary of his incompetence.
[Klingon Promotion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KlingonPromotion): By killing him in a duel, you can obtain his position for yourself.
[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): He is a highly talented Battlemage despite his many other flaws.

[The Peter Principle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePeterPrinciple): He rose in the ranks of the Mages Guild thanks to his prowess as a Battlemage. However, he is hopelessly incompetent as an administrator.
[Pointy-Haired Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PointyHairedBoss): How most of his underlings see him.

[Reassigned to Antarctica](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReassignedToAntarctica): As part of being [Kicked Upstairs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickedUpstairs), he was put in charge of the Guild branch in the most backwater district in the Empire.

[Suicide Mission](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicideMission): His mission to kill all of the Telvanni councilors, a group of [ancient](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReallySevenHundredYearsOld), powerful, [somewhat insane and morally questionable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSorcerer) wizards. May cross over with [Treacherous Quest Giver](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TreacherousQuestGiver) if one believes he was trying to get rid of the [Player Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayerCharacter) before he/she could become a threat to his position.
[Wizard Duel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WizardDuel): Challenges the player to one when your rank is high enough to threaten him. Despite his other flaws, he still *is* a very talented Battlemage.
[Freudian Excuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianExcuse): Her hatred of the Telvanni is explained by other characters who mention that the Telvanni killed her parents.

[Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation): Despite her grudge against House Telvanni, Ranis won’t interact any differently with you if you belong to House Telvanni yourself, other than the standard faction disposition adjustment.

[Join or Die](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JoinOrDie): As far as Ranis is concerned, any mage who doesn’t join the Guild should be killed. Many of her quests involving outsider mages can be successfully completed if you simply kill the mage.

[Laser-Guided Karma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaserGuidedKarma): Given her callous disregard for mages who aren't part of the Mages Guild and her [Join or Die](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JoinOrDie) mentality, when the Telvanni spy quest comes up, you can choose to lie to the Archmage and say that she's the spy, getting her kicked out of the guild.

[My Parents Are Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyParentsAreDead): Other characters mention that her parents were killed by the Telvanni. If you  (SPOILER) lie and say that she is a Telvanni spy during that particular quest , other characters are quite surprised due to this fact.
[Properly Paranoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProperlyParanoid): Despite her other flaws, she *is* correct that the Telvanni have spies within in the Guild.

[Sheltered Aristocrat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShelteredAristocrat): Some fellow members note that Ranis came from an upper class family and thus doesn’t relate well to Dunmer who grew up outside a wealthy imperialist town like Balmora.
[Stealth Expert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StealthExpert): As a Nightblade, her magic focuses on using magic to stay hidden. One of her quests also involves outing a spy.
[With Us or Against Us](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WithUsOrAgainstUs): Has this attitude toward mages outside the Guild due to her grudge against the Telvanni.
[You Killed My Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouKilledMyFather): The old Archmagister of House Telvanni killed her parents.
[Alchemy Is Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlchemyIsMagic): Uses Alchemy to brew points with various magical effects.
[Cat Folk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatFolk): Naturally, as a Khajiit.

[Fantastic Drug](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticDrug): Due to the game mechanics (only Khajiit merchants will buy Moon Sugar and Skooma), Ajira is one of the few merchants in the game who will buy your illegal drugs.
[Fetch Quest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FetchQuest): Her early quests send you off to collect things like flowers and mushrooms.

[Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation): Ajira is supposedly an Apprentice and eventually becomes a Journeyman, but if you look at her data via the construction set, you’ll see that she stays an Associate the entire game. Conversely, Galbedir is already a Journeyman when the game starts (even though the plot treats her like an Apprentice). Note that the game *does* have the functionality to raise or lower an NPC's rank, it just never uses it.

[Master Poisoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterPoisoner): She doesn’t specialize in it, but in her reports, she knows all about which ingedients have poisonous properties and how to make poisons out of them.

tropeName: Not Cheating Unless You Get Caught
tropeNotes: [Not Cheating Unless You Get Caught](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotCheatingUnlessYouGetCaught): Isn’t afraid to stoop to less than honest means to win her bet.
[Sabotage to Discredit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SabotageToDiscredit): One of her quests involves you sabotaging Galbedir's soul gem experiment.

[Stealing the Credit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StealingTheCredit): If you read her reports toward the end of her quest line, she claims to have worked hard to gather the ingredients needed for her experiments. In reality, she sent you to do this work for her.
[The Rival](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRival): To Galbedir, the Balmora Guild Hall's resident enchanter. They have a bet over who will be promoted to Journeyman first.
[Third-Person Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThirdPersonPerson): Tends to speak like this, like most Khajiit.

[True Companions](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueCompanions): Ajira is very grateful to you after you help her find her stolen reports, so much that she will give you the location of a few priceless artifacts once you advance higher in the Mages Guild.

[Adventurer Archaeologist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdventurerArchaeologist): Not her personally, but she employs them to excavate Dwemer ruins to aid in her research. A few of her quests directly involve you being this.

[Always Someone Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysSomeoneBetter): There are plenty of people better at restoring Dwemer technology than Edwinna. Not even counting the Telvanni, Ignatius Flaccus in Mourhold builds Dwemer centurions as a hobby for his warbot arena, and even the Rat in the Pot *across the street* is guarded by Dwemer [centurion spiders](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpiderMech) maintained by Estoril from the Thieves Guild. Heck, Louis Beauchamp, who stands *right outside* the Ald-Ruhn Mages Guild doorway <sup>note </sup>  with *Bloodmoon* installed  built his own Dwemer *airship*.
[Bookworm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bookworm): Is no slouch when it comes to reading, and several of her quests involve fetching books for her.

[Can't Catch Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantCatchUp): As dedicated as she is in her efforts as a Dwemer scholar, the Telvanni seem to have beat her to the punch, and at least two [Telvanni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSorcerer) [mage lords](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMagocracy) own their own custom built centurion guards. One of these mages, Baladas, is also more knowledgeable about the Dwemer than Edwinna could ever *hope* to be, having a head start in the subject of several *millennia*. The only thing saving her research from being completely pointless is that the Telvanni don’t care about sharing their findings outside their private circles, so Edwinna’s “discoveries” seem more current than they actually are.
[Glory Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlorySeeker): Implied if you show her "Secrets of Dwemer Animunculi". The reason she wants to build centurions because she thinks it will make her famous.

tropeName: Gotta Have It, Gonna Steal It
tropeNotes: [Gotta Have It, Gonna Steal It](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GottaHaveItGonnaStealIt): She really wants Sirilonwe’s book, so she sends you to “borrow” it without the owner’s permission.
[Inside Job](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsideJob): How she expects you to steal Chimeramvidium.
[Our Dwarves Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurDwarvesAreDifferent): Researches the extinct Dwemer, particularly their [robotic centurions](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MechaMooks).
[Robot Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RobotMaster): What she aspires to be, with Dwemer [Mecha-Mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MechaMooks).

[Admiring the Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdmiringTheAbomination): He sends you to capture the soul of an Ash Ghoul so he can study it and also has a few quests related to studying vampires. While not necessarily a [Nightmare Fetishist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NightmareFetishist), he does have a healthy respect for these creatures.

[And Your Reward Is Clothes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndYourRewardIsClothes): One of the few rewards he gives you for his quests is an unenchanted sapphire amulet, albeit a unique one with a greater capacity for enchantment.
[Bookworm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bookworm): He sends you on a few quests to find rare books and has a bookselling service.
[The Charmer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCharmer): As the Master Trainer for Speechcraft.

[Dude, Where's My Reward?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DudeWheresMyReward):
    - He offers you a direct reward on only a few of his quests. Luckily, for those that involve working with others (such as the scholar he asks you to escort and the Ashlander Wise Woman), they offer their own rewards. - Also Averted in a sense. Completing all of this quests opens up the "peaceful" option to become the new Arch-Mage of the Mages Guild.

[Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation): Even after delivering to him Galur Rithari’s Papers (a forbidden text about a man who was cured from vampirism), he still acts wary of you if you are a vampire and doesn’t give you any advice about how to find a cure.

[Guile Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuileHero): While other mages are known for their magical strength, Skink is known more for his ability to handle situations diplomatically (though Skink is no slouch at magic power either). That 100 Speechcraft rating is not just for show, after all.
[The Immune](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheImmune): As an Argonian, Skink is immune to poison and resistant to disease.

[Item Crafting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItemCrafting): Not directly, but Skink is the second highest Enchant trainer in the game. The only trainer better than him (the Enchant Master Trainer) lives in an obscure dungeon and attacks you on sight. When you first meet him, he is also in the middle of brewing a Detect Creature potion for Edwinna.
[Lizard Folk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LizardFolk): Naturally, as an Argonian.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): He’s more level-headed and respected than most of the other guild heads. When orders come from the mainland that Trebonius is to step down and the [Player Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayerCharacter) is to be promoted to Arch-Mage, they are delivered to Skink.

tropeName: Things Man Was Not Meant to Know
tropeNotes: [Things Man Was Not Meant to Know](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThingsManWasNotMeantToKnow): He’s interested in learning about [Vampires](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurVampiresAreDifferent) and [Sixth House Monsters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination), and sends you on quests to gather information about both.

[The Social Expert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSocialExpert): Skink is the Master Trainer for Speechcraft, though there’s little in the game that points you to this. He also sends the player on a mission to meet with an Ashlander wise woman so he can learn more about their culture. Furthermore, his branch of the Guild is in the heart of rival [Telvanni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSorcerer) territory, making his social and political knowledge even more important.
[The Witch Hunter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheWitchHunter): In one of his quests, he sends you to kill a necromancer.

[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): The Telvanni consider him such:
QUOTE  *"...almost as sage and learned as Telvanni aspirants five times his age."*
[Badass in a Nice Suit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassInANiceSuit): Is the Master Thief of the Thieves Guild and wears a full suit of "extravagant" clothing.

tropeName: Do Unto Others Before They Do Unto Us
tropeNotes: [Do Unto Others Before They Do Unto Us](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoUntoOthersBeforeTheyDoUntoUs): While he and the Thieves Guild are normally violence averse, he sends the player on some quests to kill members of other factions that are planning to kill him or other members of the Guild.
[The Don](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDon): As the head of the Thieves Guild.
[Gentleman Thief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GentlemanThief): It’s in the name. In general, he also speaks tactfully and dresses the part.

tropeName: I Know You Know I Know
tropeNotes: [I Know You Know I Know](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IKnowYouKnowIKnow): "She's [Eydis Fire-Eye] likely to betray us, too, but only if she thinks we think she won't."

[Just Like Robin Hood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustLikeRobinHood): His Bal Molagmer quests are in this vein. Named after an ancient order of thieves who stole from the rich and gave to the poor, the quests involve stealing items from the wealthy and corrupt, then giving them to the rightful owners and/or people more deserving.

[Karmic Thief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmicThief): Invokes this in his Bal Molagmer quests, where the targets are always wealthy and corrupt. For example, he has you steal a forged land deed that would give a widow's land to a wealthy plantation owner. In another, he has you steal the ring of a wealthy slaver and then give it to the leader of the Twin Lamps, an illegal slave 'freeing'' organization.

[No One Sees the Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoOneSeesTheBoss): You won't get to see him until you reach a high rank in the Thieves Guild. Justified, since he is a high priority target for the Camonna Tong and you need to prove yourself trustworthy before his location is revealed to you.
[Proud Warrior Race Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudWarriorRaceGuy): Subverted. Though he is a Redguard, he is typically violence averse and will try non-violent means to resolve problems first.
[Put on a Bus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PutOnABus): Once you’re promoted to Master Thief, he decides to take a long vacation to Hammerfell to be with his family.
[Skeleton Key](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkeletonKey): Found the eponymous artifact adventuring in Hammerfell and gives it to you at the end of the questline.

[Stop Being Stereotypical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StopBeingStereotypical): Inverted. In the *Elder Scrolls* universe, [Khajiit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatFolk) are most likely to be sterotyped as a thief. A Redguard thief in Tamriel is actually a bit unusual and unexpected.

[Violence is the Only Option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ViolenceIsTheOnlyOption): He (and the Thieves Guild in general) are normally violence averse, with murder only as an absolute last option. When it comes to high ranking enforcers for the Camonna Tong, all else (bribes, blackmail, etc.) have failed, so he sends you to kill them.

[Wide-Eyed Idealist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WideEyedIdealist): His belief in the Bal Molagmer Robin Hood type thief is mostly personal, and the other guild leaders don’t participate in it. Depending on how you play the game, he may also end up getting killed by the other local crime group, the [Camonna Tong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSyndicate).
[Cat Folk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatFolk): As a Khajiit.

[Double Entendre](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoubleEntendre): Sort of a reverse one, actually. Her name “Sugar-Lips” has a more direct meaning, but it can also be a nod to the Khajiit appetite for the illegal drug [Moon Sugar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticDrug).
[Five-Finger Discount](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FiveFingerDiscount): Her very first quest is to shoplift a diamond from a store.
[Great Escape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreatEscape): One of her quests is to break a fellow thief out of jail.
[Lockdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Lockdown): Recruits a Master of Security and is prepared to do this to protect the South Wall Cornerclub from the Camonna Tong.
[Master of Unlocking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfUnlocking): Sells high quality lockpicks once you reach a high enough rank in the guild.
[Robbing the Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RobbingTheDead): One of her quests has you steal some vintage brandy from a man who was recently killed.
[Third-Person Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThirdPersonPerson): Speaks in this fashion, as is typical of the Khajiit.
[Blackmail](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Blackmail): The intention of stealing Gandosa’s naughty book.

[Cool Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolSword): Along with [Luckily, My Shield Will Protect Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LuckilyMyShieldWillProtectMe). Despite being an expert thief, he offers moderately high level (58) training in the Long Blade, Block, and Medium Armor skills.

[Kleptomaniac Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KleptomaniacHero): His very first quest is to steal a specific tanto from the Ald-Ruhn Mages Guild Hall. The place is completely abandoned (save for one inept guard who you can kill without consequence) until you turn in the tanto, so you can steal *everything* that is not nailed down. Make multiple trips if you need to.

[Mecha-Mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MechaMooks): Tasks you with collecting Dwemer scrap metal so one of his agents can repair Dwemer [spider centurions](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpiderMech) to defend the Rat in the Pot from the Camonna Tong.
[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): His nickname “The Jeweler” may be a reference to the in-game book *The Cake and The Diamond*, which takes place in The Rat in the Pot.
[Alchemy Is Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlchemyIsMagic): Most of her quests involve stealing alchemical ingredients, alchemical equipment, or potion recipes.
[Hired Guns](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiredGuns): Tasks you to hire some mages from Wolverine Hall to defend Dirty Muriel's from the Camonna Tong.
[The Immune](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheImmune): Is highly resistant to disease, being a High Elf. She’s not so lucky against the other elements.
[Master of Unlocking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfUnlocking): Sells high quality lockpicks once you reach a high enough rank in the guild.

[Suicide Mission](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicideMission): How she sees the job to steal Felen Maryon’s staff. She’s so surprised to see you return with it that she gives you the option to just keep the staff for yourself.

[Big, Screwed-Up Family](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigScrewedUpFamily): He has a [Cain and Abel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel) situation going on with his crime boss brother, Orvas, who leads the Camonna Tong, a native Dunmer mafia-style gang of slavers, drug peddlers, and thugs who are extremely xenophobic.  (SPOILER) A late game quest (which also features into several faction quests) has you uncover evidence that Orvas is planning to assassinate Vedam.  The Camonna Tong has bribed and extorted their way into the highest levels of leadership within House Hlaalu and the Fighters Guild, giving them massive influence and resources. Finally, there is Ilmeni, the daughter of Vedam who lives as a pauper in a lower-class area of Vivec. She's active in the Twin Lamps, an illegal slave *freeing* operation, which is directly opposed to her uncle Orvas on ideological grounds, and cannot be officially supported by her father because slavery is technically legal and protected in Morrowind.

Foil: To his own brother Orvas. Both are extremely powerful political forces trying to do what they think is best for the future of Morrowind and the Dunmer people. However whereas Orvas works behind the scenes as a criminal kingpin, vehemently opposes the Imperial occupation, and is willing to get his hands dirty even if it means considering a hit on his brother, Vedam works openly as Duke of Vvardenfell, actively collaborates with the Imperials, and will go out of his way to request his brother not be killed if at all possible.

[The Good King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGoodKing): As Duke, he exercises the Empire's authority over Vvardenfell. He seems genuinely interested in protecting his people, he even says as much when asking him for a construction contract for your stronghold. If the player is in House Hlaalu, the two quests he gives involve getting some overzealous Ordinators to back down and getting his crime boss brother, Orvas, to grant the player control over the Camonna Tong.

[Klingon Promotion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KlingonPromotion): Averted. While achieving this via a [Duel to the Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelToTheDeath) is required to become the leader of the other Great Houses, Dren agrees to step down voluntarily if you tidy a few affairs for him beforehand. He figures leaving you with the headaches of being Grandmaster will give him more time to dedicate to his responsibilities as Imperial Duke of Vvardenfell.

[Knight in Shining Armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightInShiningArmor): His class is a Knight, he wears a full suit of high-quality Ebony armor, and he is quite honorable despite being the head of they notoriously corrupt House Hlaalu.
[Affectionate Nickname](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffectionateNickname): Calls the Nerevarine several dessert-based nicknames including "sweetie pie," "dumpling," and "pudding."

[Bunny-Ears Lawyer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BunnyEarsLawyer): He's an unapologetic pervert who in later games will become famed for writing "The Lusty Argonian Maid" <sup>note </sup>  while a copy appears in *Morrowind*, it is a *draft* copy you receive to help recruit an actor for a troupe to put on a first performance of it , but is by far one of the most competent figures when it comes to political maneuvering within House Hlaalu.

[Camp Gay](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CampGay): His dialogue is written this way, with him calling the Nerevarine things like "dumpling", "pudding", and "sweetie pie" while referring to himself as "Uncle Crassius." Further, he wears extravagant clothing, has written several plays, and wants to start a theater troupe. Though technically, he is a bisexual, as he shows this interest whether the PC is male or female.

[Depraved Bisexual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DepravedBisexual): If the [Player Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayerCharacter) wants to advance in House Hlaalu, he *will* see them naked first. Regardless of gender. Or species. To gain his support during the main quest so you can save the world, he'll ask for money to cover his expenses...or, if he likes you (disposition 70+), a kiss.

[Dirty Old Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyOldMan): To a degree. He's clearly dirty, and he can't be that young, as he has gotten to the position of Hlaalu councilor the hard way, but he doesn't limit himself to *young* women. Or women. Or [mammals](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExtremeOmnisexual).
[Eccentric Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EccentricMentor): Should you choose to join House Hlaalu, he will be your sponsor. "Eccentric" doesn't even *begin* to cover it...

[Extreme Omnisexual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExtremeOmnisexual): Men, women, humans, elves, [Cat Folk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatFolk), [Lizard Folk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LizardFolk)...it makes no difference to him. He *will* want to see you naked before he'll help you advance in House Hlaalu, and he *will* want a kiss from you if he likes you in order to gain his support in the main quest.

[Guile Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuileHero): His approach to fighting corruption within the House. He's not above letting everyone around him think he's an easily manipulated fool while he's at it, either.
[Her Code Name Was "Mary Sue"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HerCodeNameWasMarySue): The main character of his play, "The Lusty Argonian Maid," is named "Crantius Colto."

[Honest Corporate Executive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonestCorporateExecutive): Compared to rest of the [corrupt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive) House Hlaalu leadership. In particular, when completing quests for Odral Helvi, you can report his orders to Crassius to receive alternate, less morally offensive ways to complete the quests (and eventually even get Helvi arrested).

[Lovable Sex Maniac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LovableSexManiac): Despite his...eccentricities, he is one of only two House Hlaalu councilors who isn't in the pocket of the [Camonna](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSyndicate) [Tong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMafia) and is actively working to free the House of corruption.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): You've seen his list of tropes up to this point. "Crass" is a *very* fitting term for him. His name also evokes Crassus (reportedly the richest citizen of Rome) and Curia (a word that usually refers to an administrative council) — fitting for a councilor of the most commercial, plutocratic of the noble houses governing Morrowind.

[Obfuscating Stupidity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObfuscatingStupidity):
    - He has no problem letting others believe that he's an easily manipulated fool as he works toward his goals. - Depending on how you look at it, his entire [Dirty Old Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyOldMan) persona might be this, given how [House Hlaalu](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DecadentCourt) usually works. Forcing potential visitors to undress - while certainly creepy - helps stop assassins, and why would anyone want to spy on some bumbling fool writing erotica all day? If you compare him to other uncorrupted member of the House, (SPOILER) Dram Bero, who had to stage ["Scooby-Doo" Hoax](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScoobyDooHoax) in order to keep himself safe , he might not be that stupid at all.
[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): His creepy predilections aside, he's one of the least corrupt characters in-game.

[Take a Third Option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeAThirdOption): He will offer alternative, less morally questionable means of completing quests for some of his corrupt House Hlaalu counterparts, even leading up to getting those same people arrested for their crimes.

[Abandoned Mine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbandonedMine): If you give him the location of the lost Vassir-Didanat Ebony Mine, he will reward you with your choice in Daedric weaponry. This can be accomplished by a character [straight off the boat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneNuke).
[Character Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDeath): He is one of the Morag Tong "Grandmaster Writs".

[Gladiator Subquest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GladiatorSubquest): You'll need to battle his champion in the Vivec Arena in order to gain his support in Houes Hlaalu. Unlike the other such battles which are all a [Duel to the Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelToTheDeath), he prefers that you do not kill his champion (who will yield once his health is low enough).

[Properly Paranoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProperlyParanoid): Hides out in an allegedly haunted manor to avoid being found. If you join the Morag Tong, you'll find out this is totally justified, as one of the game's final contracts will be on his head.
["Scooby-Doo" Hoax](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScoobyDooHoax): He takes up residence behind a locked door in the back of the otherwise abandoned "Haunted Manor" in order to stay hidden.

[Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim): Has the distinction of being the only Hlaalu councillor who can be killed without disrupting your bid to become Hlaalu's Hortator. Given that he's both a foreigner and corrupt and greedy enough to try and con *the Tribunal Temple*, it's easy to see why none of the other councillors would even pretend to mourn him or refuse you for killing him.

[Character Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDeath): He will either need to be bribed or killed in order to rise to the top of House Hlaalu. Given that he's a highly corrupt jerkass, most players don't think twice about killing him. Several other councilors actually endorse the idea.

[Corrupt Church](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptChurch): While the mortal-led Tribunal Temple is very corrupt, Yngling is embezzling money from them under the guise of restoring the decrepit Hlaalu Canton Temple. You'll need to steal his ledger to prove his corruption as part of the [Thieves' Guild](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThievesGuild) "[Bal Malogmer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustLikeRobinhood)" quests.

[Rat Stomp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RatStomp): He raises prized "game rats" for use in the Vivec Arena. A rival has released a few diseased rats in with them, putting them all at risk. He gives a quest to kill all of the diseased rats.

[Abandoned Mine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbandonedMine): Along with Dram Bero, each wants to know the location of the mine once you find it. Both give inferior rewards compared to Bero (and Nevena, in fact, will give you nothing).

[Dude, Where's My Reward?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DudeWheresMyReward): Nevena will pay you nothing if you reveal the location of the Vassir-Didanat Ebony Mine to her. Velanda will at least pay you a modest sum of 2,000 gold for the information, though still not as much as Dram Bero's reward.

[Never a Self-Made Woman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverASelfMadeWoman): Both owe their positions as councilors to Orvas Dren and the Camonna Tong, to whom they are merely pawns. You'll need to bribe, blackmail, or kill Orvas in order to get their votes for Hlaalu Hortator.
[Token Evil Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenEvilTeammate): Nevena Ules. One of the very few things the other councilors agree upon is that she is the least trustworthy one among them.

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): Not actually evil, but every single quest involving him in some way includes antagonizing him somehow, whether it's stealing a poor man's heirloom he confiscated as taxes for the Thieves guild, rescuing a political prisoner he took hostage or killing him in a duel for either the title of Archmaster or Hortator. Even a minor quest for House Telvanni where you have to convince some Redoran councilors to support to change a law can have you convince every member of the council except him.
[Concealing Canvas](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConcealingCanvas): Has a hidden cell in his manor behind a tapestry for keeping political prisoners.

[Duel to the Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelToTheDeath): Whether you're seeking to rise to the top ranks of House Redoran or be named Redoran Hortator as part of the main quest, you will have to kill him in the Vivec Arena.

[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): He is hyper-xenophobic, even by traditionalist Redoran standards, and what little he will say to the player if pressed is outright vicious and hateful. He refuses to accept your promotions in House Redoran or your appointment as Hortator on the grounds that you're an outlander. He kidnaps another councilman's son on false murder charges, seemingly to punish the councilman for political differences, and is carrying on an almost public affair with another councilman's wife, despite being married himself, knowing fully well the cuckold can't do a thing about it. Whether you join House Redoran or just want to progress through the main quest, you will ultimately have to kill him because he simply can't be reasoned with.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): Despite his plethora of negative traits, he is credited with basically saving Great House Redoran. He personally secured the House's now-holdings when Vvardenfell was opened for settlement and oversaw the move of Redoran's council to Ald-Ruhn.

[The Paladin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePaladin): He is a crusader, the Dunmeri equivalent, and wears a full set of high-quality Ebony armor while wielding a Daedric dai-katana. He is also the Archmaster of Great House Redoran, one of the most pious Great Houses along with Indoril. Subverted, however, given his extreme jerkass tendencies and xenophobia.

[No Man of Woman Born](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoManOfWomanBorn): Is the subject of the in-game book *The Hope of the Redoran* which follows this. It tells the story of a Dunmeri noble named Andas, of whom it was prophesied that "his blood shall never be spilled", and that he cannot be killed by magic, illness, or poison. Indeed, the prophecy seems to come true, leading people to call Andas "The Hope Of The Redoran," in accordance with the wording of the prophecy. When he grows up, he lords this over his friends and peers as a sign of his superiority in combat, and it gives him the arrogance to challenge his cousin Athyn to a duel for an important political position. It ends with Athyn beating Andas to death with a quarterstaff, after Athyn's combat instructor gave him the idea. (Up until then, Athyn had been despairing.)
[Number Two](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NumberTwo): If completing the House Redoran questline, he will settle into this role after the Nerevarine becomes Archmaster.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Is the first Redoran Councilor to support the outlander Nerevarine for a high-ranking position in the House as well as for Redoran Hortator.
[Good Parents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodParents): Her son seems to think so, and tries to live up to her example.
[Never a Self-Made Woman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverASelfMadeWoman): Downplayed. She assumed her position after her husband's death, but does well enough that no one had a problem with it.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): She accepts the need of a Hortator for the troubles ahead in Morrowind, and readily accepts the Nerevarine. She also led House Redoran to Solstheim following the Red Year and helped keep the colony together.
[Silk Hiding Steel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SilkHidingSteel): She wears "extravagent" clothing, including a skirt, and wields a silver dagger for defense.
[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS): Wields a Dwarven Claymore.

[Corporate Warfare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorporateWarfare): Both of his House Redoran quests involve the Caldera Ebony Mine. Despite being in Redoran territory, the mining contract was granted to House Hlaalu through [unscrupulous means](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive). He first has you steal the mine's ledger to prove corruption and then has you shut the mine down by sparking a slave revolt.

[Flat-Earth Atheist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlatEarthAtheist): He doesn't actually believe in the Nerevarine prophecy, or just prophecies in general. He'll still endorse you as Hortator because [he respects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudWarriorRaceGuy) your skills and accomplishments.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): In general, his position on the Nerevarine becoming Hortator is: "Yeah, I've heard good things about you. And you're the only one willing to do anything about Dagoth Ur, so you've got my vote, sure."
[Knight in Shining Armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightInShiningArmor): His class is a Knight, he wears a full suit of Dwemer armor, and he belongs to the honorable House Redoran.

[The Lost Lenore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLostLenore): He pines for an old crush. He can be convinced to give her up for a woman close at hand, or the Nerevarine can convince this woman to return to him.
[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS): Wields a Dwarven Claymore.
[Grumpy Old Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrumpyOldMan): Unlike the other chattier councilors, he's not really fond of small talk.

[I Have Your Wife](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveYourWife): One of his daughters has been kidnapped by Telvanni Councilor Neloth. You'll have to rescue her in order to get his support in House Redoran or to become Redoran Hortator.

[The Paladin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePaladin): He is a crusader, the Dunmeri equivalent, and wears a set of Bonemold armor under (or over, in the case of the massive pauldrons) his robe while wielding a Dwarven Claymore. He is also a Councilor of Great House Redoran, one of the most pious Great Houses along with Indoril.

[Porn Stash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PornStash): His daughter has a copy of *Boethiah's Pillow Book*, a pornographic book, in her room. You'll need to steal it as part of a [Thieves' Guild](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThievesGuild) quest, with the quest giver implying that it will be used for blackmail purposes.
[The Archmage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheArchmage): As Archmagister of House Telvanni.

[The Ditherer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDitherer): According to Aryon, Gothren deals with requests he doesn't like by simply never giving an official response, stalling indefinitely until the requester just gives up and moves on. Indeed, when asking him to be named Hortator, he'll only pretend to consider it until you leave him alone. It takes *a lot* of persuasion to get him to even outright admit that, no, he really doesn't have any intention of supporting your claim, for entirely petty reasons, leaving you no choice but to kill him (though since this *is* [House Telvanni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightMakesRight), that [solves the problem](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CuttingTheKnot) anyway).
[Duel to the Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelToTheDeath): How he must be dealt with. This is in order to become Hortator or to become Archmagister of House Telvanni.
[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): Has two Dremora bodyguards who are about as dangerous as he himself is.

[Morton's Fork](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MortonsFork): If you try and get his endorsement to be named Hortator while not of House Telvanni, he'll reject you because he doesn't trust an outsider with such a prestigious role. If you *are* a Telvanni, he'll still reject you, because you're *obviously* trying to use the post to make a power grab for yourself. Either way, it makes peacefully persuading him to name you Hortator impossible.
["No. Just… No" Reaction](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoJustNoReaction): His response to being asked to give one of his daughter's hand in marriage to the Zaniab Ashkan.

[Obstructive Bureaucrat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObstructiveBureaucrat): His response to the Nerevarine asking to be named Telvanni Hortator is to constantly stall and prevaricate. Eventually, he will simply have to be killed.
[Praetorian Guard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PraetorianGuard): He is flanked by two permanently summoned Dremora who will fight to defend him if attacked.

[Benevolent Mage Ruler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BenevolentMageRuler): Downplayed. While Great House Telvanni is a [Magocracy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMagocracy) through and through, their accepted practice of [Klingon Promotion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KlingonPromotion) and belief that [Might Makes Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightMakesRight) turns the majority of their rulers in [Evil Sorcerers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSorcerer). Aryon is much more benevolent in comparison, though this benevolence is [purely out of self-interest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy).
[Fungus Humongous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FungusHumongous): Emphasizing his nature, his mushroom tower is growing out of an Imperial-style castle.
[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): As far as the Telvanni go. One of his quests involve sneaking into a mine and curing a Kwama Queen of her blight disease.
[Number Two](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NumberTwo): A Telvanni-based character will almost inevitably have him as their right hand.

[Only Sane Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlySaneMan): The rest of the council consists, as he puts it in his letter to Divayth Fyr, of traditionalists and crazies, which leaves him politically isolated. Some of his quests involve finding him some allies.

[Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy): He *seems* to be the [Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure) of House Telvanni. However, he's actually being 'flexible' because the stubbornness of the other Telvanni councilors leaves the House at a disadvantage to its numerous powerful enemies; his motives are entirely self-interested.
[So Unfunny, It's Funny](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoUnfunnyItsFunny): His response to being asked for a bride for the Zainab Ashkan. The concept is so offensive it actually makes him laugh.

[Amazon Brigade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmazonBrigade): All of the guards and retainers in Tel Mora are female. There is one lone male Telvanni guard patrolling the grounds, but this is likely a case of [Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation), as there needs to be at least one guard in the town capable of arresting the player if he/she commits a crime there. (The female guards are named and thus, not standard town guards.)

[Does Not Like Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoesNotLikeMen): Around women, she's actually quite civil. Around men, the only time she will be is if he is Archmagister of the House. And even then, she's curt. Completing the main quest as a male Nerevarine requires you to either beg at her feet for her support, kill her, or make her vote irrelevant by becoming Archmagister. She'll support a female Nerevarine with no questions asked and even gives her several powerful summoning scrolls.
[Enemy Mine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyMine): The Temple treats her as one, trying to get healers posted in her area to help the people living in her town.
