[Lady Land](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyLand): Her town of Tel Mora. All of the guards, retainers, shopkeepers, and other service providers in Tel Mora are female.

[Straw Feminist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrawFeminist): She's misandric and belittling. It takes a lot of effort, bribes, and speechcraft to get her pleasant enough to listen, and even then, grovelling is involved. Of course, given that she's a member of the cutthroat House Telvanni, simply killing her is an option. Aryon seems to suggest this to a male Nerevarine.  (SPOILER) Later, *The Elder Scrolls Online* reveals that the reason is because she traded her soul for immortality to a Dremora in order to help the Nerevarine and banned all men since the Dremora stated that he will return disguised as a mortal man.
[Axe-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxeCrazy): She is sustained by powerful necromancy even as her mind becomes progressively more psychotic, sometimes violently so.

[Beware the Silly Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareTheSillyOnes): Level 44. The things higher than that in the vanilla game can be literally counted on three fingers (specifically; [Vivec](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PhysicalGod), [Divayth Fyr](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeAbyss) and [Wulf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodWasMyCopilot)).

[Catch-22 Dilemma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Catch22Dilemma): Some of her orders are contradictory, as you'll find out. If you are in House Telvanni, you will be asked to deliver her a dress, which she will refuse to wear, unless somebody else (i.e. you) first wears them to prove they aren't dangerous. But she'll immediately attack (and usually kill) anybody shameless enough to wear her clothes. You can circumvent this by convincing a hapless Khajiit slave to wear the clothes and killed for it instead. She also has her Argonian slaves keep digging for Kwama eggs in a basically empty mine and has ordered her captain of the guard to simultaneously kill some challengers in front of the tower and not leave her side (he hires you to kill them instead).
[Character Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDeath): She's the final writ the player can receive for the Morag Tong.
[Cloud Cuckoolander](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CloudCuckoolander): She can charitably be described as "utterly nuts."
[Really 700 Years Old](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReallySevenHundredYearsOld): Implied that she is extending her life with necromantic magic.

[Sugar-and-Ice Personality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SugarAndIcePersonality): Her insanity gives her frequent mood swings. At one point, the player is asked to give her a skirt. She'll claim it's cursed and ask the player to wear it. If so, however, she'll attack the player for wearing her skirt.

[Sure, Let's Go with That](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SureLetsGoWithThat): The other Telvanni councilors note that "she hasn't aged well," and getting anything out of her requires you to play along with whatever insane story she is telling at the moment.

[Dude, Where's My Reward?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DudeWheresMyReward): He gives you a quest to retrieve the Robe of Drake's Pride from the servant of another Telvanni councilor. Killing the servant is the only way to get the robe, and you'll need to taunt her into attacking you first to prevent being expelled from House Telvanni. She turns out to be a moderately powerful spell caster, and the robe gives her several advantages when fighting magic users, which your character likely is if you've advanced far enough in House Telvanni to receive the quest. After you take the robe back to Neloth, he'll reward you with... ten septims. The robe itself is worth 205, and has several enchantments a magic-using character would enjoy.
[Fungus Humongous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FungusHumongous): The massive mushroom tower of Tel Naga in Sadrith Mora belongs to him.
[Grumpy Old Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrumpyOldMan): The majority of his dialogue options are grumpy complaints.
[I Have Your Wife](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveYourWife): He has kidnapped the daughter of a Redoran noble and is using her to influence him. A House Redoran quest sees you setting her free.
[Really 700 Years Old](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReallySevenHundredYearsOld): Like most of the other Telvanni Councilors, it is implied that he is extending his life through magic.

tropeName: This Is Wrong on So Many Levels!
tropeNotes: [This Is Wrong on So Many Levels!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThisIsWrongOnSoManyLevels): His response to being asked for a bride for the Zainab Ashkan. He repeatedly calls you stupid for even asking.

[Badass Bookworm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBookworm): He's a scholar, speaks fluent [Aldmeris](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClassicalTongue), and has extensive theories on the disappearance of the Dwemer from the Mundus. He's also a high level sorcerer with lots of magical power.

[Cunning Linguist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CunningLinguist): Proves to be one. During the Mages Guild questline, you'll come upon several books which contain clues about the disappearance of the Dwemer, including one that is written in both Aldmeris (the extinct ancestor language to many modern languages) and Dwemeri (which, to date, has not been able to be translated). Baladas can read Aldmeris and will be able to use it to translate the Dwemeri it for you.
[Grumpy Old Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrumpyOldMan): Downplayed in contrast to Neloth, but he's fairly annoyed with visitors, and he's lived in Morrowind since before the Empire came.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): Despite his age and his disposition, he's progressive enough that Divayth Fyr personally recommends that Master Aryon recruit him to the Telvanni council in order to fight back against the more isolationist members.

[Really 700 Years Old](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReallySevenHundredYearsOld): He refuses to pay taxes on the grounds that he was living there *before there was an empire*. (The first empire out of Cyrodiil, the Alessian, was founded over 3000 years prior. If the Merethic Era empire of the Nords qualifies, he's even older still.)

[These Questions Three...](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheseQuestionsThree): Inverted in a House Telvanni quest to ask Baladas three questions about the Dwemer. You can complete the quest regardless of how much Baladas likes you (which determines how specific his answers will be), but you get better rewards for warming up to him first, and getting more specific answers from him.

[Iconic Item](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IconicItem): He requires the Silver Staff of Peace to become the player's Mouth. This is the traditional gift a Councilor gives a Mouth: The player is gifted the same staff when they work for Master Aryon.
[Punny Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunnyName): "Theman" isn't particularly subtle.

[A Quest Giver Is You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AQuestGiverIsYou): Unlike most other quests in the game, the player is the one giving Fast Eddie the quests, providing him with the resources to...*procure*...valuable artifacts.
[Badass Preacher](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassPreacher): As mentioned, they have several military orders whose members are better equipped and more aggressive than your standard guards.
[Church Militant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChurchMilitant)

[Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton): Wearing the Ordinators' very own Indoril armor or [masks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MaskOfPower) (even if you obtained them legally) while talking to them will make them try to kill you on sight for the rest of the game.

[Crisis of Faith](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrisisOfFaith): The entire game is essentially one big crisis of faith for the Temple and all of their followers, seeing all their beliefs getting uprooted by a foreigner who came out of nowhere.
[Good Shepherd](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodShepherd): Many of their priests fit.
[Knight Templar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightTemplar): Particularly the Ordinators.

[The Rival](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRival): To the Imperial cult whom they compete for followers with, though they have a huge head start in their native province. That said, said rivalry isn't touched much upon in the game itself, and it is perfectly possible for a player to be part of both factions.
[Turbulent Priest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TurbulentPriest): The Dissident Priests.

[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): Very friendly and surprisingly open-minded about the prophecy, especially considering the temple is mostly known as a [Knight Templar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightTemplar) organisation.
[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy)

[Small Role, Big Impact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallRoleBigImpact): Not terribly prominent for the most part, but once you have been endorsed as Hortator and Nerevarine by the Great Houses and the Ashlander tribes, he will arrange for you an audience with Vivec to fulfil the prophecy.

[You Are in Command Now](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreInCommandNow): If you complete all the Tribunal Temple's quests he steps down to write some sermons and puts you in charge of the organization on Vvardenfell.
[Knight Templar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightTemplar): This guy is the reason why half the island is weary of the Temple's retaliation.

[Small Role, Big Impact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallRoleBigImpact): Even more so than Saryoni. He is the reason why half the province turns against you in the second act, but it is actually completely optional to talk to him at any point in the game.
[Damsel in Distress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamselInDistress): She is imprisoned at the beginning of the game's second act and must be rescued.
[The Heretic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeretic): She is at some point branded as such.
[The Mole](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMole): For the Dissident priests.
[Tomes of Prophecy and Fate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TomesOfProphecyAndFate): She specializes in these.
[Trust Password](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrustPassword): She tells you to ask the gondolier who can take you to Holamayan to "go fishing".
[Crisis of Faith](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrisisOfFaith): She's becoming increasingly unsure about the Tribunal in recent events.
[Ms Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrExposition): With high enough Disposition, she'll tell you about Almalexia and confide in you her worries about how violent Almalexia's sermons have become.

[Blue-and-Orange Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueAndOrangeMorality): Some of their customs are rather alien. In particular, they can try to kill you just for speaking to their chieftain without having received a formal carte blanche from their second-in-command.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): They are amongst the most xenophobic factions in the game, if not *the* most xenophobic. This is somewhat understandable though, because they have suffered probably the worst at the hands of foreign settlers.

[Hates Everyone Equally](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HatesEveryoneEqually): They regard the Empire as foreign invaders and the settled Dunmer as treacherous apostates. They seek to drive both of them out of their native lands.
[Magical Native American](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicalNativeAmerican): They give off this vibe, particularly in the way they dress.

[Never Learned to Read](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverLearnedToRead): They are implied to not have any native script. They pass down their traditions and stories purely orally. This is a problem when it turns out that some parts of the Nerevarine prophecy were lost to history and the place where the dissident priests come in, who collected the prophecies in their hidden monastery of Holamayan.

[Noble Savage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleSavage): The Urshilaku in particular, the most traditionalist of the tribes, are readily willing to extend clan membership to a complete outlander when the time comes to reinterpret the prophecies and, from then on, become important supporters and guides of the Nerevarine on their journey.

[Occupiers Out of Our Country](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OccupiersOutOfOurCountry): None of their tribes are stupid enough to openly rebel against the Empire, but it is stated they would do so without hesitation if there were a decent chance of success.

[Proud Merchant Race Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudMerchantRaceGuy): The Zainab are more wealthy and open to interaction with the settled people than the other tribes and have recently even started participating in the ebony trade. They also like expensive clothes and seek to establish permanent liaisons with the other factions on the island, and the Master Trainer of Mercantile is a Zainab.
[Proud Warrior Race Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudWarriorRaceGuy): Ashlanders in general are this, though the Erabenimsun are especially warlike even by their standards.
[Rape, Pillage, and Burn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RapePillageAndBurn): How the "rogue" Ashlanders, not part of any of the four major tribes, make their living.
[Good Is Not Nice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodIsNotNice): He isn't particularly friendly, even by Ashlander standards. However, he ultimately proves by far the most helpful of the various Ashkhans.

[Mr. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrExposition): He will essentially provide the most answers to the prophecy short of Vivec himself. Meeting him is the point where the plot switches from investigation on Caius Cosades' behalf to a more personal stake.
[Chubby Chaser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChubbyChaser): He would like his bride "pretty, plump and [with big hips](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HartmanHips)".

[Impossible Task](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpossibleTask): Famously, he will ask you to procure him a high-born Telvanni lady as a bride, before he bestows the title of Zainab Nerevarine upon you. [You can actually talk to the various Telvanni masters and their mouths in Sadrith Mora about it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SchmuckBait), but outside of a few amusing reactions, you won't get anything useful:
[Lovable Rogue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LovableRogue): He and his tribe are described as such by the Urshilaku.

[Obfuscating Stupidity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObfuscatingStupidity):  (SPOILER) He sees right through your and his wise-woman's attempt to trick him. However, he is just all the more impressed with your cunning for it.

[Perfectly Arranged Marriage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PerfectlyArrangedMarriage): He and Falura Hlervu, whom you procure as his bride, apparently are very smitten with each other. If you return later, Kaushad will even give you a wedding gift ([an exquisite shirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndYourRewardIsClothes)), while Falura mentions that she'd like to name [their first-born child after you](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NamedAfterSomebodyFamous).

[The Migration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMigration): The Ahemmusa have suffered quite a bit from the blight and are currently trying to migrate to Ald Daedroth, an ancient sanctuary of their people located on a small island.

[She Is the King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SheIsTheKing): Other Ashlanders refer to her as the Ashkhan of the Ahemmusa, and she functions de facto as such in all game-related matters, while also acting as their wise-woman.
[The Friend Nobody Likes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFriendNobodyLikes): Even the other Ashlander tribes don't like him and won't have any hard feelings over you killing him.

[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkAss): Unlike the other Ashkhans, he won't even consider naming you Nerevarine. Your only option is to kill him and replace him with somebody else who is willing to do so. He is also exceptionally unpleasant in general.

[Ambiguous Situation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousSituation): As part of the ambiguity surrounding the Nerevarine Prophecy, their nature is up for debate.
    - The most straightforward explanation is that they simply weren't the Nerevarine and the prophecy never referred to them, hence failing as killing Dagoth-Ur was never their destiny. - It's also possible that the prophecy was false (or self-fulfilling), and these are normal Dunmer who decided to try their hand at meeting the requirements. They had the same opportunity as the player but weren't able to for whatever reason. - It's also possible that they really are incarnations of the Nerevarine, but since they failed Azura had to try again.

[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): Conoon Chodala's plot to overthrow the Great Houses by claiming to be the Nerevarine is the subject of one of *Online*'s questlines, and the Vestige summons the other failed incarnates to disprove him.

[The Big Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBigGuy): Ranso was the most powerful warrior in the land, but martial power wasn't enough to be the Nerevarine, as you also have to convince the Dunmer to follow you.
[Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight): Aduri was one, but the path of senseless war she followed ended up leading nowhere, which is why she's a Failed Incarnate.

[Doorstop Baby](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoorstopBaby): Peakstar was washed ashore to Morrowind as a baby and taken in by an Ashlander tribe. They thought she might have been [Moses in the Bulrushes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MosesInTheBulrushes), but then she died fighting an Ash Vampire.

[Failure Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailureHero): Many of these guys were genuine heroes of the Dunmer who had the potential to fulfil the prophecy and kill Dagoth-Ur, but they are all defined by their failure to do so. Some were too warlike, like Aduri and Ranso, some not warlike *enough*, like Hort Ledd and Peakstar, some made a bad decision at some point, and some just fizzled out and died before they could reach the Nerevarine's level.

[The Fundamentalist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFundamentalist): Ane Teria was a fundamentalist paladin of the Tribunal despite being a Nerevarine candidate. Her devotion to her church was her failure, as she refused to believe the prophecy that she was the subject of until it was too late.

[Never Found the Body](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverFoundTheBody): Nobody found Peakstar's body, which led to rumors that she was still alive. She wasn't, as proven by her spirit being found in the Cavern of the Incarnates. She tells the Nerevarine she died fighting an Ash Vampire.
[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): He is rather friendly, particularly once you progress a little through the Morag Tong quest line.
[High-Class Gloves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HighClassGloves): He wears a [unique set of simple black gloves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JunkRare).

[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite):  (SPOILER) He asks you in defiance of Morag Tong laws to not kill him and simply let him retire in peace.  This is after you likely killed dozens of other people on his orders in accordance with the guild's laws. However, you can simply subvert it and kill him after all, if you want. You'll also get all the Threads of the Webspinner back that you gave him. Then again, breaking tradition here may also be good for your own health...

[Klingon Promotion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KlingonPromotion): The traditional way of becoming Grandmaster of the Morag Tong involves killing your predecessor.  (SPOILER) However, he offers to simply hand you the position in defiance of tradition instead, which you can accept if you don't want to fight him.
[Professional Killer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProfessionalKiller)

[Royal Blood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalBlood): The Hlaalu family supply the official Royal family of Morrowind under Imperial authority, although it is unknown how closely he is related to Helseth and Barenziah.<!--* TrueNeutral: The Morag Tong has literally no disposition modifiers with any other faction in the game (although this is partly as the Dark Brotherhood did not exist as a mechanical faction until ''Tribunal''). Their targets include members of all three Great Houses and a significant number of other factions besides and [[PunchClockVillain none of their writs appear to be a personal matter for the guild]].-->
[Bookworm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bookworm): Why Caius Cosades wants information from him. He has read an impressive number of books on the subject.

[Escort Mission](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EscortMission): When you meet him, he is being harassed by a couple of local thugs. He wants you to escort him to Jobasha's bookstore before he talks with you. This is easier than it sounds, because you don't even need to leave Vivec.
[Going Native](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoingNative): Though he was born and raised in Morrowind, so it is probably closer to [Immigrant Patriotism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImmigrantPatriotism).

[Now What?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NowWhat): If you return to him after finishing the main quest, he'll ask you if you now also plan to fulfill the other half of the Nerevarine prophecy; Driving all foreigners out of Morrowind and restoring the land to the traditional ways of the Ashlanders.

[Technical Pacifist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TechnicalPacifist): As a member of the Morag Tong, killing is his profession, but he refuses to harm the racist Dunmer harassing him. He could easily dispatch them himself, but he doesn't take killing lightly and would rather not make a scene or inconvenience the bartender with a brawl.

[…And That Little Girl Was Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndThatLittleGirlWasMe): During one of his quests, he tells a "little story" about a "good officer" who tried to bring criminals to justice, only for them to walk away virtually scot-free at hands of a corrupt magistrate, and now wishes for "a little bloodbath to wash the bad people away". It's very obvious the good officer is himself here.
[Karma Houdini Warranty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudiniWarranty): Tasks you with killing five Camonna Tong members who've escaped justice.
[Named Weapons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NamedWeapons): Wields a unique iron claymore with the rather ominous name of "Temreki, Shackler of Souls".

[Optional Stealth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalStealth): Completing his quest "Larrius Varro Tells a Little Story" without a bounty grants an extra reward, in the form the Speechcraft skillbook *Biography of the Wolf Queen*.
[Vigilante Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VigilanteMan): He's looking to employ the player character as one.
[Bling of War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlingOfWar): Wears an Imperial Templar Knight cuirass, shiny golden armor worn by high-ranking officers of the Imperial Legion.

[Cain and Abel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel): The Abel to his brother's (Sjoring Hard-Heart) Abel. Radd has you find scrap metal for a competition, rescue citizens of the empire, and kill legitimate threats. Sjoring  (SPOILER) uses you to take out the heads of the Thieves Guild on the behalf on the local [Generic Ethnic Crime Gang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenericEthnicCrimeGang), the Camonna Tong, as part of their [Mob War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MobWar) .

[Multi-Melee Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiMeleeMaster): As a master-at-arms, he can train you in axes, blunt weapons, and long blades, if your rank with the Imperial Legion is high enough. He himself wields an Imperial broadsword.

[Doomed by Canon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoomedByCanon): A weird twist on this trope, as he is *also* [Saved by Canon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SavedByCanon). As Carius have no scripted protection as an NPC, he can be killed during the climax of the *Bloodmoon* main quest, either by being betrayed by the Nerevarine or by fighting alongside them in combat. Canonically, however, Carius survives the ordeal as he fights alongside the Nerevarine and is later promoted to the rank of general by the Legion. His canonical death first happens during the Red Year, when Fort Frostmoth is buried in ash during the eruption of Red Mountain. The poor guy is later unfortunate enough to get resurrected into undeath by a necromancer, and appears as a minor boss faced by the Dragonborn.

[Hunting the Most Dangerous Game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HuntingTheMostDangerousGame): Identified by Hircine as one of the greatest warriors on Solstheim, he is kidnapped to take part in the Bloodmoon hunt.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Despite his stationing, he genuinely wants what is best for his men and the Empire. He gladly brings the Nerevarine into his employ, sends one of his best officers to aid in disrupting a smuggling operation, and states that he would have reassigned Antonius Nuncius if he had just asked.

[Reassigned to Antarctica](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReassignedToAntarctica): What he (and everyone else stationed there) see Fort Frostmoth as. For him personally, it also serves as being [Kicked Upstairs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickedUpstairs). He is the highest-ranking Imperial officer on the island... in perhaps the worst station in the Empire.
